Posts.Content: Welcome, though I'm sure this is not a group you exactly want to join. That's pretty bad timing - going through a divorce and PCa at the same time. My first marriage ended about 17 years ago, and I can say that it turned out to be a positive change. My second marriage is much stronger. So stay hopeful. The Walsh book has been very informative for me. Googling for information is hit-or-miss: you either find scholarly articles (tough to understand) or "lay" people's opinions, which can sometimes be off-base. Walsh is easy to read, unbiased and helpful. Good luck with everything!
Posts.Signature: DoB: 1963 Wisconsin 12-core biopsy 6/16/2016: Gleason 6, 8 % of 1 core. RALP on 8/17/2016. Final pathology: PT2a, Gleason 6, negative margins. Father died with (not of) prostate cancer & colon cancer. Prior lumbar fusion surgery & hernia repair.

Posts.Title: New Here

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kozmic This recliner thing is an issue for me. My wife wants to run out and buy a recliner, I said that seems like wasted money. I will have no use for a recliner once I'm past this. I'd hate to spend the money on it for no good reason. I wouldn't suggest buying a recliner only for recovery from a laparoscopic surgery. I had abdominal surgery in 2009 (spinal fusion) with a long incision (navel to pubic bone). I managed to get in and out of bed - just had to learn to "log roll" and use my arms to push myself up, not my abs.

Posts.Content: Hi, Sandra. Sorry to hear about your Dad. I can't offer insights on chemotherapy, but do be careful about natural remedies. A good diet, exercise, etc. can certainly improve his health and help him, but there are plenty of scammers out there trying to sell natural "cures" to desperate people. Best of luck with everything. There are lots of guys on this site with far more knowledge than I have, and they're so helpful.

Posts.Title: One year out and it was like it never happened

Posts.Content: The "countdown" to my surgery seemed to take forever, but the recovery has gone quickly. You'll be tired, bloated and sore at first, but once the catheter comes out, you'll feel 100% better. I remember thinking I was ready to go back to work at week 2, but glad I waited until week 3. By week 4, you should be good to go for sure. It sounds like you've done all you can to prepare for this. Walking post-surgery will definitely help.
Posts.Signature: DoB: 1963 Wisconsin 12-core biopsy 6/16/2016: Gleason 6, 8 % of 1 core. RALP on 8/17/2016. Final pathology: PT2a, Gleason 6, negative margins. Father died with (not of) prostate cancer & colon cancer. Prior lumbar fusion surgery & hernia repair.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Prep Question

Posts.Content: Keep in mind that lots of things can elevate PSA - including purely benign prostate enlargement. PSA increases do not automatically mean cancer. I know how much anxiety the waiting causes, but try not to worry at this point. Wait to see what the biopsy results show and go from there.

Posts.Content: Hi, Chris. It's great that you were on top of the testing and caught this early. You seem to have a positibe attitude about it all, which will serve you well. I'll bet that you will have little to no trouble with the surgery, and with a GS 6, you should find that it's confined to the prostate and that the procedure will essentially cure it. Best of luck with everything!

Posts.Title: One year ago today, 7/27/15, my world changed

Posts.Content: I had two prior abdominal surgeries - including a umbilical hernia repair with mesh just this last January. My urologist said the same thing - that this could make the surgery trickier. In the end, it was no problem. He found very little scar tissue or adhesions in my abdomen, and was able to avoid the meshed area when he made the DaVinci incisions. Turned out to be a non-issue.
Posts.Signature: DoB: 1963 Wisconsin 12-core biopsy 6/16/2016: Gleason 6, 8 % of 1 core. RALP on 8/17/2016. Final pathology: PT2a, Gleason 6, negative margins. Father died with (not of) prostate cancer & colon cancer. Prior lumbar fusion surgery & hernia repair.
Posts.Title: Da Vinci surgery and previous hernias

Posts.Content: 7. From what I've seen, it looks like final pathology only downgrades the Gleason score in 10% or less of men. It's upgraded in 20-30% and remains unchanged in the rest. (One study says that "25-35% of biopsy Gleason 6 is upgraded to Gleason 7 or higher in the prostatectomy (RP) specimen.") I couldn't find anything online describing final pathology after RP being completely negative. It's got to be less than rare. In addition, did your biopsy pathology report mention other biomarkers of PCa - like racemase? I'm not going to pretend that I understand exactly what that is, but I think that finding it bolsters the cancer diagnosis (beyond the visual appearance of the cells) - making it even less likely that the pathologist was completely wrong.

Posts.Title: Checking in After Robotic Surgery

Posts.Content: Welcome, but sorry you wound up here. Lots of more experienced folks will be along to offer advice. Can you tell us whether the Gleason 7 was (4+3) or (3+4)? That will make a difference, since 3+4 is more like a Gleason 6 and lower risk. It's great that they're getting a second pathology opinion. You'll want to take your time and learn before jumping to the conclusion that you want surgery. Some prefer to go with active surveillance - keeping an eye on your PSA and doing periodic biopsies. If you want treatment, there are several radiation therapies that offer equally effective cures. A lot of us here have relied on Dr. Patrick Walsh's "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer." I'd suggest you get a copy and spend some time reading it. You have time to learn and make choices before deciding what you want to do.

You'll want to take your time and learn before jumping to the conclusion that you want surgery. Some prefer to go with active surveillance - keeping an eye on your PSA and doing periodic biopsies. If you want treatment, there are several radiation therapies that offer equally effective cures. A lot of us here have relied on Dr. Patrick Walsh's "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer." I'd suggest you get a copy and spend some time reading it. You have time to learn and make choices before deciding what you want to do.
Posts.Signature: DoB: 1963 Wisconsin 12-core biopsy 6/16/2016: Gleason 6, 8 % of 1 core. RALP on 8/17/2016. Final pathology: PT2a, Gleason 6, negative margins. Father died with (not of) prostate cancer & colon cancer. Prior lumbar fusion surgery & hernia repair.
Posts.Title: Just got the bad news

Posts.Content: Ooh, sorry to hear this. I've had spine surgery through the abdomen and then hernia surgery (with mesh). My urologist says scar tissue from those procedures could complicate RALP. I hope your issues resolve quickly.
Posts.Signature: DoB: 1963 Wisconsin 12-core biopsy 6/16/2016: Gleason 6, 8 % of 1 core. RALP on 8/17/2016. Final pathology: PT2a, Gleason 6, negative margins. Father died with (not of) prostate cancer & colon cancer. Prior lumbar fusion surgery & hernia repair.
Posts.Title: Surgery Complications

Posts.Content: I can't give you any insights about the prednisone, but I'm glad to hear you're recovering well from the surgery. It's encouraging.
Posts.Signature: DoB: 1963 Wisconsin 12-core biopsy 6/16/2016: Gleason 6, 8 % of 1 core. RALP on 8/17/2016. Final pathology: PT2a, Gleason 6, negative margins. Father died with (not of) prostate cancer & colon cancer. Prior lumbar fusion surgery & hernia repair.
Posts.Title: 3-Week Post-DaVinci Update - and a Question

Posts.Content: I can't give you any insights about the prednisone, but I'm glad to hear you're recovering well from the surgery. It's encouraging.
Posts.Signature: DoB: 1963 Wisconsin 12-core biopsy 6/16/2016: Gleason 6, 8 % of 1 core. RALP on 8/17/2016. Final pathology: PT2a, Gleason 6, negative margins. Father died with (not of) prostate cancer & colon cancer. Prior lumbar fusion surgery & hernia repair.
Posts.Title: 3-Week Post-DaVinci Update - and a Question

Posts.Content: I had DaVinci surgery on Aug. 17, and the recovery is going well, 11 days out. I'm 99.9% continent, and it already looks like hardly any ED side effects. Mild discomfort from the surgery, especially the bloating, but I needed painkillers less than a week. The worst part was probably dealing with the %^&* catheter. Margins were negative, and it was all confined to one lobe (PT2a). I go back for PSA testing in a few weeks, but the likelihood of recurrence is less than 1%. I hope that gives some relief to those worried about the surgery. Everybody's experience is different, but for me, it's been really just a bump in the road. Thanks again for all the information, guys. This site helps a lot of folks.
Posts.Signature: DoB: 1963 Wisconsin 12-core biopsy 6/16/2016: Gleason 6, 8 % of 1 core. RALP on 8/17/2016. Final pathology: PT2a, Gleason 6, negative margins. Father died with (not of) prostate cancer & colon cancer. Prior lumbar fusion surgery & hernia repair.
Posts.Title: Checking in after successful surgery

Posts.Content: Sorry, my info wasn't too clear. They took 12 biopsy samples. The cores on the right had PIN cells. On the left, one of the 4 cores had the cancerous cells. (The report says some of the cores sent to the lab were "tiny" - to small to test, I think.) Thanks for the suggestions! I'm keeping an open mind about various options for treatment.
Posts.Signature: DoB: 1963 Wisconsin 12-core biopsy 6/16/2016: Gleason 6, 8 % of 1 core. RALP on 8/17/2016. Final pathology: PT2a, Gleason 6, negative margins. Father died with (not of) prostate cancer & colon cancer. Prior lumbar fusion surgery & hernia repair.
Posts.Title: New guy

Posts.Content: Thought I'd introduce myself. I'm 53 and was diagnosed with prostate cancer just five days ago, so I'm just starting to learn about all this. (I'm reading the Dr. Walsh book now.) Based on what I know so far, it was caught early and I'm in a low-risk category. I've got a Gleason score of 6 (3+3) and a PSA of just 0.6 ng/mL. Nothing unusual was felt with DRE. My cancer was caught only because I had a 10-month history of hematospermia (blood in semen). No other symptoms. They assumed prostatitis, but when antibiotics did nothing and the bleeding continued, a new urologist suggested a biopsy to rule out anything serious. Imagine my surprise. I will meet with my urologist again in two weeks to discuss treatment options in more detail, and I am seeing a different urologist for a second opinion soon after that. (Also, awaiting lab results on whether PTEN is absent.) My initial reaction is that prostatectomy seems best, given my age and life expectancy (dad lived to 87). But I'm keeping an open mind, and I'd welcome any suggestions. One question: I'll ask the doctors about the number of RPs they've done, rates of complications, how much incontinence their patents reported 3, 6, 12 month out, etc. (Q's that Dr. Walsh's book suggests.) Is there any resource that compiles that sort of information and makes it publicly available?

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> <Z> I'm 53 and was diagnosed with prostate
